medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The patient experienced an episode of rectal bleeding the evening before admission, presenting with four to five bowel movements containing bright red blood. Symptoms of rectal bleeding began at around three and a half years of age and continued intermittently over the next 40 years, often requiring blood transfusions.
medical_history.past_medical_history: At age 15 days, the patient had Escherichia coli sepsis and a subdural hematoma, leading to residual left-sided weakness and mild mental retardation. He had recurrent complex partial seizures controlled with phenobarbital. The patient underwent several surgical procedures including subtotal colectomy at age 25 for intractable rectal bleeding, and laparotomies for intussusception and bowel obstructions at ages 23, 26, and 42. Notable conditions also included iron-deficiency anemia, epistaxis, and multiple gastrointestinal polyps characterized as juvenile or hamartomatous.
medical_history.family_history: The patient's mother had a subtotal colectomy at 13 years of age due to rectal bleeding and associated conditions. History of gastrointestinal cancer is noted in the mother, who later died of sepsis at age 45. No other immediate family members reported bleeding issues.
